3. The interplay between civil damages and CICS awards is crucial to understand. The documentation mentions that "CICS awards are reduced based on civil damages already paid, because you can't be compensated twice for the same injury." This means the client can potentially receive the higher civil damages if the perpetrator can pay, or fall back on the CICS if not, ensuring maximum possible compensation.

4. This strategy also accounts for the psychiatric trauma, which could be compensated under both systems (Chapter 4 of the Judicial College Guidelines for civil claims, and potentially under CICS for violent crime victims).

Option A is incomplete because it doesn't account for the perpetrator's limited resources or the potential CICS safety net. Option B likely results in lower compensation, as CICS awards are generally lower than civil damages. Option D is risky, as it may undervalue the claim and doesn't utilize the CICS safety net.

This question tests critical thinking by requiring integration of multiple concepts, understanding of real-world application, and analysis of the most effective strategy given the specific circumstances.

documentation.title: Can I leave my friend my body if I die
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: So when I die I want my friend to keep my body parts in a jars and maybe make a mask out of my face or some thing like that. Can I do that? I’m only 17 so idk if my parents would have a say or if a will would even work for me being in parental control. Anyways thanks 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: It depends on where you live. In Washington, [RCW 68\.50\.110](https://app.leg.wa.gov/RCW/default.aspx?cite=68.50.110) requires that

> Except in cases of dissection provided for in RCW 68\.50\.100, and where
>  human remains are rightfully carried through or removed from the state
>  for the purpose of burial elsewhere, human remains lying within this
>  state, and the remains of any dissected body, after dissection, must
>  be decently buried, undergo cremation, alkaline hydrolysis, or natural
>  organic reduction within a reasonable time after death.

Per [RCW 68\.50\.130](https://app.leg.wa.gov/RCW/default.aspx?cite=68.50.130),

> Every person who performs a disposition of any human remains, except
>  as otherwise provided by law, in any place, except in a cemetery or a
>  building dedicated exclusively for religious purposes, is guilty of a
>  misdemeanor. Disposition of human remains following cremation,
>  alkaline hydrolysis, or natural organic reduction may also occur on
>  private property, with the consent of the property owner; and on
>  public or government lands or waters with the approval of the
>  government agency that has either jurisdiction or control, or both, of
>  the lands or waters.

So cutting the body up and sticking the bits in a jar is illegal, but cremating or dissolving it and keeping the remains in a jar is legal. 

As for parental permission, [RCW 68\.50\.160](https://app.leg.wa.gov/RCW/default.aspx?cite=68.50.160) says that

> A person has the right to control the disposition of his or her own
>  remains without the predeath or postdeath consent of another person. A
>  valid written document expressing the decedent's wishes regarding the
>  place or method of disposition of his or her remains, signed by the
>  decedent in the presence of a witness, is sufficient legal
>  authorization for the procedures to be accomplished.

It does not require that the person be an adult.

95.answer:
Question: A 17-year-old individual in Washington state wants to ensure their body parts are preserved in jars and their face is made into a mask after death. Which of the following approaches would be most legally compliant while still adhering as closely as possible to their wishes?

A) Create a valid written document expressing their desire for the body to be dissected and preserved as requested, to be carried out immediately after death
B) Specify in a will that their body should be cremated, with the ashes to be kept in decorative jars and a plaster cast made of their face before cremation
C) Designate a friend as the legal custodian of their body after death, granting them full authority to carry out the preservation requests
D) Obtain parental consent for the body preservation plan, which would override any legal restrictions once the individual turns 18

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: This question requires analysis of multiple legal concepts from the provided documentation and application to a real-world scenario. The correct answer is B because:

1. According to RCW 68.50.110, human remains must be "decently buried, undergo cremation, alkaline hydrolysis, or natural organic reduction within a reasonable time after death." Keeping body parts in jars would violate this law.

2. RCW 68.50.130 states that disposition of human remains following cremation may occur on private property with the owner's consent. This allows for keeping ashes in jars legally.

3. RCW 68.50.160 confirms that a person has the right to control the disposition of their remains through a valid written document, regardless of age. This supports the legality of specifying cremation in a will.

4. Making a plaster cast of the face before cremation is not explicitly prohibited and would allow for a mask-like memento without violating laws against keeping actual body parts.

Option A is incorrect because dissection and preservation of body parts as described would be illegal. Option C is incorrect because designating a friend doesn't override legal restrictions on body disposition. Option D is incorrect because parental consent doesn't supersede state laws on body disposition, and turning 18 wouldn't change the legality of the original request.

This question tests the ability to integrate multiple legal concepts, apply them to a specific scenario, and find a solution that best balances the individual's wishes with legal requirements.

documentation.title: Good Samaritan law
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: What exactly is the Good Samaritan law? Can someone please explain the Good Samaritan law? What is the Good Samaritan statute? How would someone apply the law in LaSalle County Illinois?

Edit: After reading some comments and answers, how would this apply in a situation where you were trained for cpr/first aid, called assistance to someone threatening suicide, and ended up with charges against you for assisting by calling for aid? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: In [Illinois](http://www.ilga.gov/legislation/ilcs/ilcs3.asp?ActID=2076&ChapterID=58):

> The General Assembly has established numerous protections for the
>  generous and compassionate acts of its citizens who volunteer their
>  time and talents to help others.

Basically, if you are a licensed medical profession, or have had successful training in CPR provided by the the American Red Cross or the American Heart Association, and you try in good faith to save somebody's life and fail, you are not liable for their death, under the assumption you did not cause harm in the first place (i.e. you can not stab someone in the chest, attempt CPR, and be exempt from lawsuit(s)). 

Note that this doesn't apply to just CPR or physicians. This also covers dentists, Pharmacists, Optometrists, Physical Therapist, etc.

B) The EMT has no protection under Good Samaritan laws because they are a trained professional.
C) The EMT is protected only if they can prove the family explicitly requested their help.
D) The EMT's protection depends on whether they caused the initial harm requiring intervention.

Correct Answer: D

However, this protection is contingent on the rescuer not having caused the initial harm. The law assumes the EMT "did not cause harm in the first place." Options A and B are incorrect because they oversimplify the law's application. While the EMT's training and adherence to protocols are relevant, they don't guarantee full protection (A), nor does being a professional negate protection entirely (B). Option C introduces a misconception about explicit consent, which isn't a requirement under this law. The question tests the understanding of the law's nuances and its application in a real-world scenario, requiring integration of multiple concepts from the documentation.

documentation.title: Self defense damages
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: Someone attacks me. I punch them in self defense. During the punch I dislocate my shoulder.

Are there civil damages incurred when I injured myself in self defense and got a medical bill?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Yes
---

Assuming you were [assaulted](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assault_(tort)) (with or without battery) and you suffered injury (physical or otherwise) during that assault you are entitled to damages. The injury has to flow from the assault but not necessarily from the assaulter. For example, if you fled across the road and were struck by a car you could sue your attacker.

Because assault is an intentional tort, it is not necessary for you to prove that actual financial loss was [suffered](https://websterslawyers.com.au/personal-injury-assaulted) \- this is not negligence. The court can assess economic loss, non\-economic loss and exemplary (punitive) damages.

Question: A martial arts instructor is demonstrating a self-defense technique to her class when a student unexpectedly attacks her, mistaking the demonstration for a real practice session. The instructor instinctively counters with a defensive move, but in doing so, tears her rotator cuff. Which of the following statements most accurately describes the legal implications of this scenario?

A) The instructor cannot claim damages as the injury was self-inflicted during a voluntary demonstration.
B) The student is liable for the instructor's medical bills, but not for any non-economic damages.
C) The instructor can potentially sue for both economic and non-economic damages, including punitive damages.
D) The instructor can only claim damages if she can prove negligence on the part of the student.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: This scenario involves several key concepts from the provided documentation. The correct answer is C because:

1. The student's unexpected attack constitutes an assault, which is an intentional tort.
2. The documentation states that "the injury has to flow from the assault but not necessarily from the assaulter." In this case, the instructor's injury (torn rotator cuff) resulted from her defensive action in response to the assault.
3. The answer states that for intentional torts like assault, "it is not necessary for you to prove that actual financial loss was suffered." This means the instructor doesn't need to prove negligence or specific financial losses.
4. The documentation mentions that "The court can assess economic loss, non-economic loss and exemplary (punitive) damages." This supports the potential for both economic (medical bills) and non-economic damages, as well as punitive damages.

Option A is incorrect because self-defense against an assault is not considered voluntary in a legal sense. Option B is partially correct but incomplete, as it doesn't account for non-economic and punitive damages. Option D is incorrect because proving negligence is not necessary in cases of intentional torts like assault.

This question requires the integration of multiple concepts, applies them to a real-world scenario, and tests critical thinking about legal principles rather than mere memorization.

documentation.title: Why was an American who overstayed in Singapore not caned?
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: The US citizen Kamari Kenyada Charlton overstayed his visa while in Singapore. The [law](https://sso.agc.gov.sg/Act/IA1959#pr6-) is that this shall "be punished with caning with not less than 3 strokes".

However, according to [this story](https://www.asiaone.com/print/News/AsiaOne%2BNews/Crime/Story/A1Story20110221-264712.html), he was jailed 18 months for his telephone scam and seems to not have received any punishment for overstaying. Why?

More background:

* [*WSJ*, "U.S. Man Faces Caning in Singapore", Oct 20 2010](https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304011604575564012145605090)
* [*WaPo*, "U.S. citizen faces possible caning in Singapore", Oct 22 2010](http://voices.washingtonpost.com/checkpoint-washington/2010/10/us_citizen_faces_possible_cani.html)"
* [Gopalan Nair, "Singapore. One law for some and another for others. The case of American Kamari Kenyada Charlton", Feb 21, 2011](http://singaporedissident.blogspot.com/2011/02/singapore-one-law-for-some-and-another.html)

---

The caning punishment is regularly enforced for overstayers from poor Asian countries (and also any who aid such overstayers):

* [*Channel News Asia*, "Foreign inmate diagnosed with COVID\-19 had arrived on Jan 10, sentenced to jail and caning on Jun 12 for overstaying", 20 Jun 2020](https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/covid-19-changi-prison-inmate-overstaying-jail-12854542) (Sri Lankan)
* [*Yahoo News*, "Vietnamese man who overstayed in Singapore for over 10 years gets jail, caning", 2 April 2019](https://sg.news.yahoo.com/vietnamese-man-overstayed-singapore-10-years-gets-jail-caning-113447453.html)
* [*The Straits Times*, Indonesian gets two years' jail for attempt to sneak overstayer out of Singapore, Jul 8 2016](https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/courts-crime/indonesian-gets-two-years-jail-for-attempt-to-sneak-overstayer-out-of)
* [*Today*, Man convicted for helping Bangladeshi overstayer: ICA, 28 March 2017](https://www.todayonline.com/singapore/bangladeshi-overstayer-arrested-after-attempting-leave-singapore-ica)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: [Plea bargain](https://www.straitstimes.com/opinion/plea-bargaining-singapore-style)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Probably.

Like all common law jurisdictions, Singapore practices plea bargaining. While not formalised as it is in the USA, a prosecutor can agree to drop certain charges and/or not pursue certain sentences in return for a guilty plea to others.

As it says in your link, the defendant “pleaded guilty to five charges last week.
17 other charges, including one for overstaying in Singapore, were taken into consideration.”

So, he was *not* convicted of overstaying his visa.

documentation.title: On the Term "Commercial Use" and the Usage of an Apparently Free Font
documentation.text:
\#\#\# User: I am in the process of finishing up a book which I anticipate will be published in the United States.

For the book's cover, I would like to make use of a font that is freely downloadable; and, *as far as I can tell*, does not forbid commercial use. In this case, I would like to make use of a font available from [https://www.schäffel.ch/de\_gruppe1\.html](https://www.xn--schffel-7wa.ch/de_gruppe1.html).

Now, I say, "as far as I can tell", for German is not my native language, and although I did not determine that "commercial use" is forbidden, I also did not detect anything along the lines of "free for commercial use."
